Relevance meets Diversity: A User-Centric Framework for Knowledge Exploration through Recommendations

Erica Coppolillo 0000-0002-4670-8157 University of CalabriaDepartment of Computer ScienceRendeItaly ICAR-CNRRendeItaly erica.coppolillo@unical.it ,  Giuseppe Manco 0000-0001-9672-3833 ICAR-CNRRendeItaly giuseppe.manco@icar.cnr.it  and  Aristides Gionis 0000-0002-5211-112X KTH Royal Institute of TechnologyDivision of Theoretical Computer ScienceStockholmSweden argioni@kth.se
Abstract.

Providing recommendations that are both relevant and diverse is a key consideration of modern recommender systems. Optimizing both of these measures presents a fundamental trade-off, as higher diversity typically comes at the cost of relevance, resulting in lower user engagement. Existing recommendation algorithms try to resolve this trade-off by combining the two measures, relevance and diversity, into one aim and then seeking recommendations that optimize the combined objective, for a given number of items to recommend. Traditional approaches, however, do not consider the user interaction with the recommended items.

In this paper, we put the user at the central stage, and build on the interplay between relevance, diversity, and user behavior. In contrast to applications where the goal is solely to maximize engagement, we focus on scenarios aiming at maximizing the total amount of knowledge encountered by the user. We use diversity as a surrogate of the amount of knowledge obtained by the user while interacting with the system, and we seek to maximize diversity. We propose a probabilistic user-behavior model in which users keep interacting with the recommender system as long as they receive relevant recommendations, but they may stop if the relevance of the recommended items drops. Thus, for a recommender system to achieve a high-diversity measure, it will need to produce recommendations that are both relevant and diverse.

Finally, we propose a novel recommendation strategy that combines relevance and diversity by a copula function. We conduct an extensive evaluation of the proposed methodology over multiple datasets, and we show that our strategy outperforms several state-of-the-art competitors. Our implementation is publicly available 111https://github.com/EricaCoppolillo/EXPLORE.

1. Introduction

Recommender systems play a significant role in helping users discover new information and expand their knowledge base. Notable examples are the adoptions of recommendations for finding news articles or books to read (Alharthi et al., 2018; Wu et al., 2023; Zihayat et al., 2019), listening to enjoyable music (Hansen et al., 2020; Schedl et al., 2015), visiting interesting locations (Xie et al., 2016; Yin et al., 2013), and more. Recommender systems aim to predict and leverage users’ interests to identify the portions of the catalog that match them, thus enabling efficient exploration of vast volumes of information and offering benefits ranging from increased personalization and user satisfaction to improved engagement and resource efficiency.

Recommenders are primarily focused on maximizing relevance. However, from the standpoint of knowledge exploration, incorporating diversity into recommendations adds significant value, as emphasized in earlier research (Herlocker et al., 2004; Smyth and McClave, 2001). Indeed, providing diverse recommendations can be critical in mitigating detrimental consequences, such as being trapped in rabbit holes in platforms like Youtube (O’Callaghan et al., 2015; Tufekci, 2018; Ribeiro et al., 2020; Haroon et al., 2022) or Reddit (Phadke et al., 2022), where the algorithm may lead the user to consume limited types of content.

To achieve a balance between relevance and diversity, current methods merge these two metrics into a single objective for optimization. However, they overlook user behavior and how users interact with the recommended list of items. For instance, typical approaches assume a fixed number of interactions between the user and the algorithm, disregarding any reactions or refusals from the user during the exploration process. Indeed, users might reject recommended items and quit the process.

In this paper we propose a new framework for recommender systems, where we place the user at the forefront. We consider the interaction of the user with the algorithm to be a knowledge-exploration task, where recommendations enable exploration. The interaction of the user with the system is guided via a user-behavior model, i.e., the propensity of a user to accept or reject recommendations according to their preferences and patience. As the objective is to maximize the amount of knowledge that a user acquires during exploration, we model the knowledge accrued by the user using a diversity measure, which we consequently aim at maximizing. Notably, although diversity is the sole optimization objective, the coupling of the exploration task with the user-behavior model implies that the recommendation system is required to produce recommendations that are both relevant and diverse.

We illustrate the proposed concept of “knowledge exploration via recommendations” with the following example.

Example. Alice interacts with a news recommender system for finding interesting news articles to read. The knowledge-exploration process is iterative, and is depicted in Figure 1. At each step, the system recommends a set of news articles to Alice, and Alice clicks on some article to read. At some point, Alice can decide to quit, either because she received enough information, or because the recommendations are not very interesting to her, or simply because she got bored. Our goal is to design a recommender system that maximizes the amount of knowledge received by Alice. The challenge is to strike a balance between diversity and relevance to keep Alice engaged while exploring interesting topics, avoiding scenarios where recommendations are either too focused (Figure 2(a)) or too diverse and irrelevant (Figure 2(b)). Our aim is to create an ideal scenario (Figure 2(c)) where Alice explores many relevant yet diverse topics, enriching her knowledge.

Motivated by the previous example, we propose a novel framework where relevance governs the termination of exploration, while the overall quality is measured by diversity. We instantiate our model using two standard notions of diversity, one based on coverage and the other based on pair-wise distances (Ashkan et al., 2015; Carbonell and Goldstein, 1998; Chen et al., 2018). Both diversity notions, coverage and pairwise distances, can be defined using an underlying space of user-to-item ratings or categories/topics.

Finally, we propose a novel recommendation strategy that combines relevance and diversity by a copula function. We perform an extensive evaluation of the proposed framework and strategy using five benchmark datasets publicly available, and show that our strategy outperforms several state-of-the-art competitors.

Our contributions are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We develop a user-centric model for knowledge exploration via recommendations; our framework takes into consideration the interplay among relevance, diversity, and user behavior.

  • •

    We instantiate our model with two diversity measures, defined over user-to-item ratings or categories/topics.

  • •

    We propose a recommendation strategy that accounts for both diversity and relevance when providing suggestions.

  • •

    We conduct an extensive analysis over multiple benchmark datasets and several competitors to show the effectiveness of our proposal in the suggested framework.

The rest of the paper is structured as follows. Section 2 presents the related work in terms of user modeling and diversity in recommendations. Section 3 presents our problem definition and methodology. In Section 4 we present our recommendation strategy. Experimental results are reported in Section 5, and finally Section 6 concludes the paper and provides pointers for future extensions.

2. Related work

User modeling in recommender systems. The effects of user behavior in recommender systems, in terms of novelty and diversity, have gained a lot of attention in recent years. Analysis can be conducted by either running user studies (Lee and Hosanagar, 2014, 2017; Matt et al., 2013; Zhu et al., 2018), or by means of simulation (Hazrati et al., 2020; Szlávik et al., 2021; Yao et al., 2021). Analyzing the choices made by actual users can yield more dependable outcomes; however, it also requires creating an effective recommendation system and engaging users for conducting comprehensive studies.

On the other hand, simulating user choices is a more straightforward method, allowing for testing several system configurations at no expense. However, it requires a realistic model of user behavior. To address this challenge, several user-behavior models have been proposed in the literature. Hazrati and Ricci (2022) model the probability that a user picks a recommended item as being proportional to the utility of the item. Similarly, Bountouridis et al. (2019) propose a simulation framework in which users decide to interact with a certain number of items per iteration, according to their given preferences. Szlávik et al. (2021) present three different user-behavior models, by imposing that users either blindly follow recommendations and choose the most popular items, or completely ignore suggestions and pick items randomly.

The aforementioned models present certain limitations, namely users necessarily have to pick an item, i.e., they cannot leave the application, and second, the selection probability stays constant over time. We overcome these limitations by modeling a quitting probability, according to which users can interrupt their interaction with the recommender system. We assume that the quitting probability depends on the utility of the recommended items and on the user patience, which degrades over time.

Notably, with our framework, we leverage the intrinsic interplay among relevance, diversity, and user behavior, since successful recommendation strategies need to ensure that they provide recommendations that are both relevant and diverse.

Diversity in recommendation. Diversity in recommendations has been acknowledged as a crucial issue (Castells et al., 2022; Herlocker et al., 2004; Smyth and McClave, 2001; Ziegler et al., 2005), and over the past decade, it has received considerable attention (Adamopoulos and Tuzhilin, 2014; Adomavicius and Kwon, 2012; Celma and Herrera, 2008; Hurley and Zhang, 2011; Vargas and Castells, 2011). Several online and targeted user studies assessed the increase in user satisfaction when diversity is incorporated into the list of suggested items (Hurley and Zhang, 2011; Castells et al., 2022). For example, Allison et al. (Chaney et al., 2018) show that, if diversity (besides other objectives) is not taken into account, the interactions between users and recommender systems are prone to homogenization and, consequently, low utility.

The challenge of striking a balance between diversity and relevance has been explored both in the context of recommender systems and in the broader domain of information retrieval. For instance, one of the most popular methods in the literature of information retrieval is the maximal marginal relevance (MMR) (Carbonell and Goldstein, 1998). It employs a weighted linear combination of scores that evaluate both utility and diversity, offering a systematic way to address this critical aspect. In the specific context of recommender systems, Ziegler et al. (2005) introduced one of the earliest methods for enhancing diversity. They use a greedy selection approach, where they pick items that minimize the similarity within a recommended list. Liu et al. (2012) present a solution based on random walks for the so-called accuracy-diversity dilemma, i.e., the challenge in finding a profitable trade-off between the two measures. This concept is also known as calibration, as mentioned by Steck (2018), and refers to the algorithm’s capability to produce suggestions that do not under-represent (or ignore) the user’s secondary areas of interest.

Several re-ranking strategies have also been introduced: Ashkan et al. (2015) propose to greedily select items by maximizing the utility of a submodular function; Sha et al. (2016) suggest to optimize the diversity loss of items using probabilistic matrix factorization; Chen et al. (2018) propose a determinantal point process (DPP) to re-rank the recommended items so as to maximize the determinant on the items’ similarity matrix. Hansen et al. (2021) investigate the impact of diversity on music consumption, and propose two innovative models: a feed-forward neural ranker that produces dynamic user embedding, and a reinforcement learning-based ranker optimized on the track relevance. Reinforcement learning is indeed a suitable solution for addressing the diversity problem. It plays a role in the work by Parapar and Radlinski (2021), where diversity is induced by adopting multi-armed bandits in the elicitation phase; and in the online learning framework proposed by Yue and Guestrin (2011), where diversification is obtained by carefully balancing the exploration and exploitation of users’ preferences and interests. Notably, these reinforcement learning-based approaches typically require a lengthy training phase, which can often be prone to stability issues.

Several other neural-network models have been applied to address the diversity problem. Gao et al. (2022b) adopt a variational autoencoder to induce targeted (i.e., topical) diversity. Liang et al. (2021) propose a bilateral branch network to achieve a good trade-off between relevance and diversity, defined at either domain or user level. Zheng et al. (2021) present a graph neural network for diversified recommendations, where node neighbors are selected based on inverse category frequency, together with negative sampling for inducing diverse items in the embedding space.

In contrast to most of the approaches mentioned earlier, the recommendation strategy we introduce, explore, does not necessitate any form of training or hyperparameter tuning, it is computationally efficient, and is shown to provide both highly relevant and diverse suggestions.

3. User model and problem formulation

We consider a typical recommendation setting in which we have a set of m𝑚mitalic_m users 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U and a set of n𝑛nitalic_n items ℐℐ\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I. We also consider a function ℛ:𝒰×ℐ→ℝ:ℛ→𝒰ℐℝ\mathcal{R}:\mathcal{U}\times\mathcal{I}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}caligraphic_R : caligraphic_U × caligraphic_I → blackboard_R that provides us with a relevance score ℛ⁢(u,i)ℛ𝑢𝑖\mathcal{R}(u,i)caligraphic_R ( italic_u , italic_i ), for each user u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U}italic_u ∈ caligraphic_U and item i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}italic_i ∈ caligraphic_I. We assume that the function ℛℛ\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R can be computed by a black-box method, and state-of-the-art relevance-scoring functions can be employed, such as content similarity (Pazzani and Billsus, 2007), collaborative filtering (Schafer et al., 2007), or a combination of both (Burke, 2007). Our goal in this paper is to create lists of diverse recommendations using as a black box such relevance-scoring functions, rather than devising a new relevance-scoring function ℛℛ\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R.

We do not investigate what is the best distance function to be used, as this is orthogonal to our study and beyond the scope of this paper.

User model. A central aspect of our approach is that we aim to evaluate the quality of a recommendation algorithm 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S in the context of the user response to items recommended by 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S. We view the user-algorithm interaction as a dynamic knowledge-exploration process, in which the algorithm recommends items to the user, and the user interacts with the recommended items. The knowledge-exploration process continues as long as the recommended items are of interest to the user. If the recommended items are not interesting enough (meaning, if they have low relevance for the user) the user may (stochastically) decide to quit.

To formalize the exploration process between the user and the recommendation algorithm 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S, which is needed to evaluate the quality of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S, we propose a user model. Our model is specified in terms of a relevance-scoring function ℛℛ\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R, which guides the behavior of the user, and in terms of a recommendation algorithm 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S, which enacts the choices within 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S.

Our user model, which formalizes knowledge-exploration as an iterative process, is described as follows.

  1. (1)

    The set of items that the user interacts with during the exploration process is denoted by 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. Initially 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is empty.

  2. (2)

    In the t𝑡titalic_t-th step, the recommendation algorithm 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S generates a list of items 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to present to the user. The user examines these items in a specified order.

  3. (3)

    At any point in the current step, the user has the option to quit. The likelihood of quitting (to be quantified later) depends on two factors: the relevance of the recommended items and the user’s patience. If the user fails to find interesting items in list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or if they stochastically run out of patience, they may opt to conclude the exploration process.

  4. (4)

    If the user does not quit, with a certain probability that depends on the relevance of the recommended items (and which we quantify later), they select an item i𝑖iitalic_i from the list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and interact with it. The item i𝑖iitalic_i is added to the set 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X and the exploration process continues.

  5. (5)

    Upon quitting, the total score achieved by the recommendation algorithm 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S is determined to be div⁢(𝒳)div𝒳\mathrm{div}(\mathcal{X})roman_div ( caligraphic_X ), where divdiv\mathrm{div}roman_div is one of our diversity functions, divCsubscriptdiv𝐶\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{C}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or divDsubscriptdiv𝐷\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{D}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This score reflects the diversity in the items the user has interacted with throughout the exploration process. We denote the final number of steps performed by the user as κ𝜅\mathrm{\kappa}italic_κ.

Algorithm 1 depicts the overall exploration process.

To fully specify the user model we need to describe in more detail the probability that the user selects an item to interact with, as well as the probability of quitting the exploration. Before presenting more details about these aspects of the model, we first formalize the problem of designing a recommendation algorithm in the context of our user model.

The recommendation task (problem statement). The algorithmic problem that we address in this paper is the following.

Problem 1.

Given a set of items ℐℐ\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I, a set of users 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U, a relevance-scoring function ℛ:𝒰×ℐ→ℝ:ℛ→𝒰ℐℝ\mathcal{R}:\mathcal{U}\times\mathcal{I}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}caligraphic_R : caligraphic_U × caligraphic_I → blackboard_R, a diversity function div:2ℐ→ℝ:div→superscript2ℐℝ\mathrm{div}:2^{\mathcal{I}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}roman_div : 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R, and a user model for knowledge-exploration as the one described in the previous paragraph, the goal is to design a recommendation algorithm 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S that maximizes the diversity score div⁢(𝒳)div𝒳\mathrm{div}(\mathcal{X})roman_div ( caligraphic_X ) for the set of items 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X that a user u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U}italic_u ∈ caligraphic_U interacts with.

Item selection. We now discuss step (4) of the iterative knowledge-exploration user model presented in the previous paragraph, that is, we specify how we model the probability that a user selects an item i𝑖iitalic_i from the list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to interact with. We first assume that a user does not quit exploration, i.e., that they have enough patience to explore the whole 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and that they find at least a relevant item within it (see next paragraph). In that case, the user selects an item i𝑖iitalic_i from 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability proportional to the relevance of i𝑖iitalic_i for that user u𝑢uitalic_u, that is, pi=ℛ⁢(u,i)∑j∈𝐋tℛ⁢(u,j)subscript𝑝𝑖ℛ𝑢𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝐋𝑡ℛ𝑢𝑗p_{i}=\frac{\mathcal{R}(u,i)}{\sum_{j\in\mathbf{L}_{t}}\mathcal{R}(u,j)}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG caligraphic_R ( italic_u , italic_i ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R ( italic_u , italic_j ) end_ARG. As noted before, the selected item i𝑖iitalic_i is added to the set of interacted items 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X.

Quitting exploration. Last, we discuss step (3) in our user model, that is, how we model the probability that a user quits the exploration process. A sensible model for the quitting probability is crucial in our knowledge-exploration model, since we want to mimic user behavior as realistically as possible. In particular, we take into consideration two aspects: (i𝑖{i}italic_i) users decide to interact with the recommended items according to their relevance; and (i⁢i𝑖𝑖{ii}italic_i italic_i) users’ desire for exploration degrades with time, i.e., users get bored.

In the model we propose, a user examines the items in the list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sequentially. Upon examining an item i∈𝐋t𝑖subscript𝐋𝑡i\in\mathbf{L}_{t}italic_i ∈ bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the user decides with probability ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡{\eta}_{t}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to quit exploration due to worn out at step t𝑡titalic_t. We refer to this as the weariness probability. The weariness probability ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡{\eta}_{t}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is discussed in more detail below, models the user’s decline of interest in exploration as a function of time, and it depends on the current step t𝑡titalic_t in the exploration process.

If the user does not quit, they decide whether item i𝑖iitalic_i is interesting to explore. The latter is decided again stochastically with Bernoullian probability qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is a function of the relevance score ℛ⁢(u,i)ℛ𝑢𝑖\mathcal{R}(u,i)caligraphic_R ( italic_u , italic_i ).222In our experiments, qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is obtained by normalizing ℛ⁢(u,i)ℛ𝑢𝑖\mathcal{R}(u,i)caligraphic_R ( italic_u , italic_i ) into the [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ] interval by considering the maximum relevance range. Thus, the probability qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT models the user’s interest in an item according to its relevance. The examination of the list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT continues until the user decides to quit or decides that there is at least one item that is interesting to explore. Thus, the probability that the user quits examining the list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT without identifying any item to explore is

The last ingredient in our model is to quantify the weariness probability ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡{\eta}_{t}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at step t𝑡titalic_t. This probability models the user’s increasing impatience or boredom as their interaction continues. To achieve this, we employ the Weibull distribution (Papoulis and Unnikrishna Pillai, 2002), which has been previously used to model web page dwell times and session lengths in web page navigation (Liu et al., 2010).

The Weibull distribution is described by two parameters, λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ and γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, where λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0italic_λ > 0 is the scale parameter and γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0italic_γ > 0 is the shape parameter of the distribution. In particular, we set the weariness probability ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡{\eta}_{t}italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by resorting to the discrete version of the Weibull Distribution (Rinne, 2008):

(5) ηt=1−q(t+1)γ−tγ,subscript𝜂𝑡1superscript𝑞superscript𝑡1𝛾superscript𝑡𝛾{\eta}_{t}=1-q^{(t+1)^{\gamma}-t^{\gamma}},italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 - italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where q=e−1/λγ𝑞superscript𝑒1superscript𝜆𝛾q=e^{-1/\lambda^{\gamma}}italic_q = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_γ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 0≤q≤10𝑞10\leq q\leq 10 ≤ italic_q ≤ 1.

The shape parameter γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ controls the “aging” of the process. For γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1italic_γ = 1 the weariness probability remains constant, and the resulting distribution becomes an exponential distribution, while for γ>1𝛾1\gamma>1italic_γ > 1, the weariness probability increases over time — modeling the tiredness of the user.333 For γ<1𝛾1\gamma<1italic_γ < 1 the weariness probability decreases over time.

In this case, there will be exactly one coin-flip for quitting exploration for each list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and thus, Qt=ηtsubscript𝑄𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡Q_{t}={\eta}_{t}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_η start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for all t𝑡titalic_t. The expected number of steps 𝔼⁢[steps]𝔼delimited-[]steps\mathbb{E}\!\left[{\mathrm{steps}}\right]blackboard_E [ roman_steps ] examined by a user before quitting (or equivalently, the number of items in 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X) is hence given by

Although lacking closed-form analytical expressions, Khan et al. (1989) show that it is bounded by the expectation μ=λ⁢Γ⁢(1+1/γ)𝜇𝜆Γ11𝛾\mu=\lambda\,\Gamma(1+{1}/{\gamma})italic_μ = italic_λ roman_Γ ( 1 + 1 / italic_γ ) of the Weibull distribution in the continuous setting (Papoulis and Unnikrishna Pillai, 2002) as

(8) μ<𝔼⁢[steps]<μ+1,𝜇𝔼delimited-[]steps𝜇1\mu<\mathbb{E}\!\left[{\mathrm{steps}}\right]<\mu+1,italic_μ < blackboard_E [ roman_steps ] < italic_μ + 1 ,

which provides an algebraic relationship between the λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ parameter of the Weibull distribution and the admissible range for the expected number of steps.

Note that, if the relevance of the recommended items is less than 1, it is possible to get more than one coin-flip for quitting exploration in each list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this case, the right-hand side of Equation (7) provides an upper bound on the expected number of steps during exploration.

A notation table can be found in the Appendix (Table 7).

Remarks on the proposed model. We observe that, as intended, our model captures both the relevance of the recommended items and the natural tiredness of users with exploration over time. For fixed values of the Weibull distribution parameters λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ and γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, which control scaling and aging, the users’ time for exploration increases with the relevance of the recommended items. Furthermore, the ordering of the items in the list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is important, and thus, we are viewing the recommendation list as a sequence, and not just as a set. This aspect would have implications on how to pick the appropriate recommendation strategy, but also on the objective (diversity) function, since it can affect the choices of the user.

4. Recommendation strategy

In this section, we present our recommendation strategy for the proposed knowledge-exploration framework. Recall that the recommendation task is displayed as Problem 1.

The core of the problem is to construct a list of recommendations 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of size ‖𝐋t‖=knormsubscript𝐋𝑡𝑘\|\mathbf{L}_{t}\|=k∥ bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ = italic_k for the t𝑡titalic_t-th step of exploration, for a given user u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U}italic_u ∈ caligraphic_U. We assume that 𝒳tsubscript𝒳𝑡\mathcal{X}_{t}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the set of items that the user has interacted with at step t𝑡titalic_t, where 𝒳1=∅subscript𝒳1\mathcal{X}_{1}=\emptysetcaligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∅. We define 𝒥t=ℐ∖𝒳tsubscript𝒥𝑡ℐsubscript𝒳𝑡\mathcal{J}_{t}=\mathcal{I}\setminus\mathcal{X}_{t}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_I ∖ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be set of items that are available for recommendation, that is, all items except the ones that the user has already interacted with.

Given 𝒫i∈{ℛi,𝒯i}subscript𝒫𝑖subscriptℛ𝑖subscript𝒯𝑖\mathcal{P}_{i}\in\{\mathcal{R}_{i},\mathcal{T}_{i}\}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ { caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, we also denote the min-max normalization of the score 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P as 𝒫^i=(𝒫i−𝒫𝑚𝑖𝑛)/(𝒫𝑚𝑎𝑥−𝒫𝑚𝑖𝑛)subscript^𝒫𝑖subscript𝒫𝑖subscript𝒫𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝒫𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝒫𝑚𝑖𝑛\mathcal{\widehat{P}}_{i}=({\mathcal{P}_{i}-\mathcal{P}_{\mathit{min}}})/({% \mathcal{P}_{\mathit{max}}-\mathcal{P}_{\mathit{min}}})over^ start_ARG caligraphic_P end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / ( caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where 𝒫𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝒫𝑚𝑎𝑥\mathcal{P}_{\mathit{max}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝒫𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝒫𝑚𝑖𝑛\mathcal{P}_{\mathit{min}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the maximum and minimum values of 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P, respectively, over all items in 𝒳tsubscript𝒳𝑡\mathcal{X}_{t}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Our strategy for constructing the recommendation list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is to combine relevance and diversity into one score. For each item i𝑖iitalic_i with relevance ℛisubscriptℛ𝑖\mathcal{R}_{i}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and diversity 𝒯isubscript𝒯𝑖\mathcal{T}_{i}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we compute the combined score 𝒵isubscript𝒵𝑖\mathcal{Z}_{i}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by adopting the Clayton copula function (CLAYTON, 1978)

(10) 𝒵i=[ℛ^i−α+𝒯^i−α−1]−1/α,subscript𝒵𝑖superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript^ℛ𝑖𝛼superscriptsubscript^𝒯𝑖𝛼11𝛼\mathcal{Z}_{i}=\big{[}\mathcal{\widehat{R}}_{i}^{-\alpha}+\mathcal{\widehat{T% }}_{i}^{-\alpha}-1\big{]}^{-1/\alpha},caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ over^ start_ARG caligraphic_R end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + over^ start_ARG caligraphic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where α>0𝛼0\alpha>0italic_α > 0 is a regularization parameter. The list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is then formed by selecting the top-k𝑘kitalic_k items from 𝒥tsubscript𝒥𝑡\mathcal{J}_{t}caligraphic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT according to their combined score 𝒵isubscript𝒵𝑖\mathcal{Z}_{i}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We refer to this strategy as explore. When the distance diversity function is used we refer to it as explore-⁢Dexplore-𝐷\text{{\large explore}-}\scriptstyle\mathit{D}smallcaps_explore - italic_D, and when coverage diversity is used we refer to it as explore-⁢Cexplore-𝐶\text{{\large explore}-}\scriptstyle\mathit{C}smallcaps_explore - italic_C. A final word on the justification of using the copula function (10). Copulas are functions able to model the cumulative joint distribution of uniform marginal distributions. In general, they are used to represent correlation and dependencies of high-dimensional random variables (Wang and Wang, 2019; Peng et al., 2023; Zeng and Wang, 2022; Novianti et al., 2021). The Clayton copula function approaches 1 when both the input variables u,v𝑢𝑣u,vitalic_u , italic_v are maximized, and it is minimized when either of them is 0. The α𝛼\alphaitalic_α parameter governs the steepness and folding of the surface: the higher the value of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, the more stooped the function is when u=v𝑢𝑣u=vitalic_u = italic_v.

The complexity of the algorithm is discussed in the Appendix.

5. Experiments

In this section, we assess the performance of our recommendation strategy, either explore-⁢Dexplore-𝐷\text{{\large explore}-}\scriptstyle\mathit{D}smallcaps_explore - italic_D or explore-⁢Cexplore-𝐶\text{{\large explore}-}\scriptstyle\mathit{C}smallcaps_explore - italic_C, in balancing accuracy and diversity. We also compare its effectiveness with several state-of-the-art competitors within the proposed knowledge-exploration framework.

5.1. Datasets

We use five benchmark datasets, freely available online. We ensure that all datasets have category information, which is used by our diversity measures.

Movielens-1M (Harper and Konstan, 2015):555https://grouplens.org/datasets/movielens/1m/ A popular dataset with movie ratings in the range [1,5]15[1,5][ 1 , 5 ], and movie genres.

Coat (Schnabel et al., 2016):666https://www.cs.cornell.edu/~schnabts/mnar/ Ratings on coats in the range [1,5]15[1,5][ 1 , 5 ], and information on coats’ properties.

KuaiRec-2.0 (Gao et al., 2022a):777https://kuairec.com/ A recommendation log from a video-sharing mobile app. Context information is provided, such as play duration, video duration, and watch ratio. We convert the watch ratios into ratings by interpolating the values from [0,2]02[0,2][ 0 , 2 ] to [1,5]15[1,5][ 1 , 5 ], where 0 represents “never watched” and 2 represents “watched twice.” We use the small version of the dataset.

Netflix-Prize (Bennett and Lanning, 2007):888https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/rishitjavia/netflix-movie-rating-dataset Movie ratings in the range [1,5]15[1,5][ 1 , 5 ]. We adopt a smaller sample of the original dataset by randomly selecting 5 000 items and discard the users with less than 20 interactions. Movie categories are acquired from a dataset using the IMDB database.999https://github.com/tommasocarraro/netflix-prize-with-genres.

Yahoo-R2:101010https://webscope.sandbox.yahoo.com/catalog.php?datatype=i&did=67 Song ratings in the range [1,5]15[1,5][ 1 , 5 ]. Each item is accompanied by artist, album, and genre information. We randomly sample 3 000 items and discard users with less than 20 interactions.

Table 1 provides a summary of the dataset properties, which include the number of users (—𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U—), the number of items (—ℐℐ\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I—), the number of ratings (#Ratings), and the distribution of item distances, calculated based on either users or categories. During our experiments, we use Equation (1) with the distance that exhibits the lowest mean for each dataset. This approach helps us avoid potential bias from large distance values, which could otherwise hinder the effectiveness of the approaches.

5.2. Competing recommendation strategies

We evaluate our recommendation algorithm, explore, against the following baseline and state-of-art strategies that have been designed for the task of increasing diversity in recommender systems.

Relevance: This approach recommends the k𝑘kitalic_k most relevant items, making it a fundamental baseline. Since this strategy is solely focused on maximizing relevance, it represents the most straightforward and basic diversity method, and any other approach must outperform it to be deemed effective.

Maximal marginal relevance (MMR) (Carbonell and Goldstein, 1998): A classic method used to balance relevance and diversity, performed by optimizing the following marginal relevance:

MMR=argmaxi∉L{β⁢ℛ⁢(u,i)−(1−β)⁢maxj∈L⁡Si,j},MMRsubscriptargmax𝑖𝐿𝛽ℛ𝑢𝑖1𝛽subscript𝑗𝐿subscriptS𝑖𝑗\mbox{MMR}=\operatorname*{argmax}_{i\notin L}\left\{\beta\,\mathcal{R}(u,i)-(1% -\beta)\max_{j\in L}\textbf{S}_{i,j}\right\},MMR = roman_argmax start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∉ italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_β caligraphic_R ( italic_u , italic_i ) - ( 1 - italic_β ) roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ,

where Si,j=1−d⁢(i,j)subscriptS𝑖𝑗1𝑑𝑖𝑗\textbf{S}_{i,j}=1-d(i,j)S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 - italic_d ( italic_i , italic_j ). In our experiments, we set β=0.5𝛽0.5\beta=0.5italic_β = 0.5.

DUM (Ashkan et al., 2015): This strategy aims at diversifying the suggestions by performing the following diversity-weighted utility maximization:

Hence, the function maximizes the relevance of the recommended items weighted by the increase in their coverage.

DPP (Chen et al., 2018): This method utilizes determinantal point processes and maximizes diversity by iteratively selecting the item i𝑖iitalic_i that maximizes the determinant of the item-item similarity matrix S defined on a subset of items:

where wyisubscript𝑤subscripty𝑖w_{\textbf{y}_{i}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the weight for each sample based on its category, λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ is a regularization factor, and ℒBPRsubscriptℒBPR\mathcal{L}_{\mbox{\footnotesize BPR}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BPR end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the Bayesian personalized ranking loss (Rendle et al., 2009) .

Notably, these competitors exhibit significant heterogeneity both in terms of the approaches they employ as well as the specific diversity functions they aim to optimize.

5.3. Experimental setting

To evaluate the performance of the examined recommendation strategies, we divide user interactions into a training and a test set, following an 80-20% split ratio. When evaluating the accuracy, we only focus on the recommendation list generated in the initial exploration step. Regarding diversity, we consider the complete set of recommendation lists produced across all exploration steps. Our approach also assumes that the entire item catalog is accessible to every user during the simulation.

To calculate the relevance score ℛ⁢(u,i)ℛ𝑢𝑖\mathcal{R}(u,i)caligraphic_R ( italic_u , italic_i ), we employ a black-box model in the form of a neural network based on matrix factorization (Koren et al., 2009). We fine-tune the latent factors of this model for each dataset. For explore, we use a value of α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5italic_α = 0.5 in the Clayton copula. Additionally, we conduct hyperparameter tuning for this parameter, and it appears that it has no significant impact on the results (further details can be found in the Appendix).

We keep the length of the recommendation list, 𝐋𝐋\mathbf{L}bold_L, fixed at 10, and vary the expected number of steps, 𝔼⁢[steps]𝔼delimited-[]steps\mathbb{E}\!\left[{\mathrm{steps}}\right]blackboard_E [ roman_steps ], in the range of [5, 10, 20]. This allows us to devise a suitable value for the Weibull parameter λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ to be used in the simulation experiments, according to Equation (7). To assess recommendation quality, we use standard metrics: Hit-Ratio (HR), Precision, and Recall. Our experimental results are the average of 20 independent trials, and we use the ANOVA test (Girden, 1992) to evaluate statistical significance. The code used in these experiments is made publicly accessible.111111https://github.com/EricaCoppolillo/EXPLORE

5.4. Results

Quality-diversity trade-off. We initiate our evaluation by assessing the performance of all our strategies in terms of recommendation quality and diversity. Figure 3 displays the scores for Recall@10 (on the x𝑥xitalic_x-axis) and coverage-based diversity (on the y𝑦yitalic_y-axis) across all five datasets. The figure shows that on all datasets, MMR and DGREC exhibit notably poor performance with respect to Recall@10. In contrast, the other strategies achieve significantly higher scores, with the Relevance baseline performing the best, which aligns with our expectations.

In terms of diversity, our method, explore-⁢Cexplore-𝐶\text{{\large explore}-}\scriptstyle\mathit{C}smallcaps_explore - italic_C, clearly outperforms the other strategies. It achieves a substantially higher diversity score while still delivering relevant recommendations. In fact, it strikes the best trade-off between diversity and relevance. Similar results, both in terms of diversity measures and other evaluation metrics, can be found in the Appendix for reference.

Best performing diversity strategy. Table 2 presents a comprehensive analysis of divDsubscriptdiv𝐷\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{D}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, divCsubscriptdiv𝐶\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{C}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and κ𝜅\mathrm{\kappa}italic_κ when 𝔼⁢[steps]=5𝔼delimited-[]steps5\mathbb{E}\!\left[{\mathrm{steps}}\right]=5blackboard_E [ roman_steps ] = 5. Additionally, we report the deviations from the maximum diversity scores in terms of distance and coverage (reported in the Appendix), denoted as ΔD¯subscriptΔ¯𝐷\Delta_{\bar{D}}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ΔC¯subscriptΔ¯𝐶\Delta_{\bar{C}}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_C end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, along with Δ𝔼⁢[steps]subscriptΔ𝔼delimited-[]steps\Delta_{\mathbb{E[\mathrm{steps}]}}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_steps ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We observe that our strategy, either explore-⁢Dexplore-𝐷\text{{\large explore}-}\scriptstyle\mathit{D}smallcaps_explore - italic_D or explore-⁢Cexplore-𝐶\text{{\large explore}-}\scriptstyle\mathit{C}smallcaps_explore - italic_C, consistently outperforms the competitors in terms of both divDsubscriptdiv𝐷\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{D}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and divCsubscriptdiv𝐶\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{C}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT across all datasets. We also show how these values deviate from the expected maximum values. Notably, on the Movielens-1M dataset, their scores are very close to their maxima. Our strategy achieves significantly higher scores than the competitors on all datasets, especially in terms of coverage.

Regarding the number of steps, as mentioned in Section 3, the relevance plays a fundamental role in our exploration process. Therefore, it is expected that our strategy performs slightly worse than other competitors, particularly the Relevance baseline. Nevertheless, our primary objective is to maximize recommendation diversity while maintaining relevance as high as possible. Additional details on the experiments are in the Appendix.

Ablation study. In our final investigation, we explore the advantages of combining both relevance and diversity through the copula function in Equation (10), in contrast to a simpler strategy that neglects relevance and relies on Equation (9).

We can observe that the combination has a positive effect both in terms of diversity and number of steps.

6. Conclusion and future work

In this study, we addressed recommendation diversity by introducing a user-behavior model where relevance drives engagement. We devised a recommendation strategy that optimizes the delivery of diverse knowledge to users in accordance with the underlying user behavior. The experimental analysis confirms that our approach is effective, yet it remains open to further enhancements. First, the behavioral model can be refined to encompass more sophisticated scenarios. These include alternative actions such as refreshing the list or guiding its composition, and incorporating dynamic adjustments to the weariness probability beyond temporal decay. Also, our model assumes that the underlying relevance score captures a user’s actual interest in an item. However, the relevance score is computed through an algorithm that is not necessarily totally accurate. We can still adapt the user behavior model to account for such inaccuracy by incorporating a random discount factor associated with the relevance of each item in the list. Finally, the proposed strategy can be improved in several ways: for example, by integrating different distance measures or tailoring it to encompass additional metrics beyond diversity, such as serendipity or fairness.

Appendix A Appendix

Complexity. In the following, we analyze the computational complexity of the proposed algorithm explore. Besides the (black-box) recommender system, the critical point is the generation of list 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be presented to users, where t𝑡titalic_t is an exploration step in a session. Within an online setting, this list has to be dynamically generated and hence can represent a bottleneck. For the generation of 𝐋tsubscript𝐋𝑡\mathbf{L}_{t}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we need to consider Equations 9 and 10. By considering that 𝒳tsubscript𝒳𝑡\mathcal{X}_{t}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is computed incrementally, the cost of computing 𝒯isubscript𝒯𝑖\mathcal{T}_{i}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in 9 is O⁢(t⁢d)𝑂𝑡𝑑O(td)italic_O ( italic_t italic_d ) when adopting divDsubscriptdiv𝐷\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{D}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and O⁢(|𝒞|)𝑂𝒞O(|\mathcal{C}|)italic_O ( | caligraphic_C | ) when adopting divCsubscriptdiv𝐶\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{C}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here, d is the computational cost associated with the Jaccard distance. In total, the worst-case cost for generating a list of k elements by considering n𝑛nitalic_n items is either O⁢(n⁢d⁢k2)𝑂𝑛𝑑superscript𝑘2O(ndk^{2})italic_O ( italic_n italic_d italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) or O⁢(n⁢k⁢|𝒞|)𝑂𝑛𝑘𝒞O(nk|\mathcal{C}|)italic_O ( italic_n italic_k | caligraphic_C | ).
We can observe the following. (1) The number n𝑛nitalic_n of items to consider could be large (in principle, the entire item catalog). However, since 𝒯isubscript𝒯𝑖\mathcal{T}_{i}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is combined with ℛisubscriptℛ𝑖\mathcal{R}_{i}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation 10, we can filter out low-relevance items, as they will severely affect the value of 𝒵isubscript𝒵𝑖\mathcal{Z}_{i}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT due to the properties of the copula function. Notice also that, in a practical implementation, sampling strategies on portions of the catalog can also be devised to narrow the focus only on a subset of items. (2) The cost d𝑑ditalic_d for computing d⁢(i,j)𝑑𝑖𝑗d(i,j)italic_d ( italic_i , italic_j ), for two generic items, can be O⁢(m)𝑂𝑚O(m)italic_O ( italic_m ), where m𝑚mitalic_m is the total number of users. To relieve this cost, the scores for popular items can be precomputed. Notice that in typical settings the distribution of items is heavy-tailed, thus we can expect that the number of distance scores to precompute is not intractably large.
Figure 6 shows that indeed our strategy exhibits comparable running times with those of other strategies, while significantly overcoming competitors such as MMR and DPP (that struggle especially with large datasets).

Experiments. We present additional experiments regarding the recommendation quality of the strategies, the diversity scores, and the run time required to provide the recommendation list.

Figures 4 and 5 show the trade-off between recommendation quality and diversity, either in terms of divDsubscriptdiv𝐷\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{D}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or divCsubscriptdiv𝐶\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{C}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and either {Recall, HR, Precision}@10. Further, Tables 4(d) and 5(a) report the scores in terms of divDsubscriptdiv𝐷\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{D}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, divCsubscriptdiv𝐶\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{C}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, κ𝜅\mathrm{\kappa}italic_κ, ΔD¯subscriptΔ¯𝐷\Delta_{\bar{D}}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_D end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ΔC¯subscriptΔ¯𝐶\Delta_{\bar{C}}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_C end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Δ𝔼⁢[steps]subscriptΔ𝔼delimited-[]steps\Delta_{\mathbb{E}\!\left[{\mathrm{steps}}\right]}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_steps ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, obtained by varying the expected number of steps in the range [5, 10, 20].

As we can see, our algorithm, for both variants explore-⁢Dexplore-𝐷\text{{\large explore}-}\scriptstyle\mathit{D}smallcaps_explore - italic_D and explore-⁢Cexplore-𝐶\text{{\large explore}-}\scriptstyle\mathit{C}smallcaps_explore - italic_C, outperforms the competitors for most of the datasets, offering a significant improvement especially in terms of coverage.

Notably, despite the fact that in some settings explore-⁢Dexplore-𝐷\text{{\large explore}-}\scriptstyle\mathit{D}smallcaps_explore - italic_D obtains a slightly lower divDsubscriptdiv𝐷\mathrm{div}_{\!{}_{D}}roman_div start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT score than DPP, it is crucial to consider the timing needed to provide the recommendation list, reported in Figure 6. As we can see, competitors such as MMR and DPP require a considerable amount of time to compute their recommended lists, in particular for the largest datasets. Our algorithm, instead, proves to be much more efficient, and its running time is basically constant over all the benchmarks.

In Figure 7 we show the effect of tuning the α𝛼\alphaitalic_α parameter of the Clayton copula function. As we can see, the parameter value does not affect the performance of the algorithm, thus proving explore to be free of hyper-parameter tuning.
